title: Data Science Through the Lens of Social Science
segmentation: So as many of you know who you're here, this is the invited talks track, which means I get to come here and talk to you having not gone through any of the rigorous peer review of the papers that all of you submitted to be here, which basically means I get to come up here and do a little bit of pontification and a little bit of substance.

And in fact, the talk is sort of designed as a pontification sandwich, where there's pontification in the beginning, little substance in the middle, and then a little bit more pontification at the end.
So if you're prepared for that, please come along for the journey.

So the first thing that I want to start with again, the beginning here is I want to talk about social science as a lens into data science or or for my part, why I think social science is such an important part of the data science as a discipline an I want to start by sort of telling a story this young woman.
Let's say her name is Kelly and choosing in elementary school and she's very fortunate because her elementary school actually provides her.
Excuse me with some CSS classes so she's actually learning how to program, which is.
Fantastic, right?
Most students don't act.
We get an opportunity to do that, and they're getting and she's getting this opportunity to sort of enrich her ability to ask questions.

Observe the world, build algorithmic ways of interpreting what she sees, and even at that young age, right, she starts to embark on this data science journey as she grows up, she consumes all of the mathematical, statistical, computational knowledge that she can.
She's really enriching her, her base knowledge of all the fundamental things that she needs to know to really interpret the world around her.
And from that knowledge she takes it and she started doing a bunch of projects on her own.
She's hacking in her free time.
She's learning again how to build these models of the world so she can interpret them.
She graduated from a top University, she she goes off and increases our knowledge through University, and is fortunate enough to have gotten into a top University.

And then when she finishes, she lands a really lucrative job at an ad tech company where she gets to take all of that knowledge and apply it to a very particular field of getting people or predicting.
Who's going to click on what or what ads should be served?
But I want to go back now, so we've gone through this very brief journey with Kelly.
I want to go back to this.
This original young lady who was sitting in front of this terminal thinking you know, wow, there's this whole world out there of questions.
I'm really interested in how people make choices right, and I will.
I would contend that young lady never thought that she would be using that information to serve ads right now.

Young hacker really grows up thinking this is the area of expertise that I'm honing so that I can understand how people make choices about clicking on something on the screen, and I know that you know, there's great great knowledge that's being generated from the ad tech world, many, many of whom invited me to speak here today, and I love you guys.
But you know my my point here is that there's the question is why do so many people end up doing that today, right?
Why do young people who go on this journey?
Enter into the job market or enter into this field and end up in industry doing this sort of work and my my position on this is that it's a it's a problem of definition.
Right?
I love this slide.
This isn't my slide.
I stole this from somebody else, but the idea is that the words have no longer have any meeting big data data science innocence doesn't really have any meaning.
If you Google Image search big data.
This is what you get.

This is this is the journey that were meant to go on as a discipline really as an industry and actually think that we're in a very important moment of sort of reflection about where it is that this industry actually is.
Right now.
We're not here.
I hope we're not here.
This is absurd, or.
I think we're here and I can't see any of you, otherwise I'd ask this question.
Anybody know who this is or what we're looking at in sort of roughly make out raised hands?
Doesn't look like anybody knows, so those are the Ramones, and those are the Ramones performing at CBG Bees at once.
Great pantheon of punk rock here in New York City.
So why do I put the Ramones on the screen when we're talking about Big Data?
Well, I think that big data is actually very similar to punk rock, right?
Let's think about punk rock.
Punk Rock was was a musical movement in the beginning of particular genre of rock and roll had a very, very particular vibe.
And attracted a very very particular audience, right?
Eventually punk rock lived on to be a cultural movement.
It sort of move beyond the artists who are performing it beyond the actual songs and the places that it was being performed, and embodied an entire cultural movement around music.

I actually think that we're in the same moment with big data and data science, big data and data science started as the essentially asking the question was what can we do with all these web log server files that we've mostly been using for server audits all these years?
Is there any information in there that's interesting?
Well, it turned out there was a lot of information that was in there that was interesting.
So we developed an entire ecosystem of technologies that we've heard people talk about today and at other conferences to actually support that endeavour.
Right now we're in a different place now.

I think we're at the point in the cultural movement of big Data, and that's really where I want to frame the beginning of this talk, which is again, my perspective is as a social scientist, and the part of the cultural movement of Big data that I found most interesting is that now we can sort of get beyond the hand ring or.

Technology and get to the interesting questions and the areas that we can start to move big data into to actually solve hard problems, solve important problems, not necessarily just solve technology problems.
And so, as was mentioned, this is a thing I made long time ago.
People seem to have liked it.
I'm very glad that it helped people sort of crystallize or have a better sense of what my definition of data science was.

And I'm very happy that others have sort of shared this conceptualisation of a very disparate discipline that most people sort of either reject it outright because of the name, and eventually have come around to accept.
But what I want to do here is sort of get past.

That first bubble that hacking skills bubble have sort of hold it to be self evident that everybody in this room is at least at a certain common denominator on that, and I want to talk about the other bubbles and where I think it's important for social science to exist in those things and how I think social science can contribute to the discipline of data science as it is with this.
With this as the definition.
So.
This is a quote that's existed for a very, very long time.
I think it certainly can be challenged, but if we take it to be truthful, that is better.
Data beats better math, right?
This is like, I think it's a jealous quote.
Basically, the idea is the more data you have, the less math you have to think about this simple model.
Simple models start to do much better when you have much more observed values.
Certainly challenge Aghbal statement, but let's take it to be self evident.
So if that is the case, what methods should we be teaching?
Or should we be thinking about?
For data science, is a discipline.
Again from this lens.
Well, I think we should sort of split the methods into two components that embody the most important phases of the discipline.
First, the exploration.
We get a new data set.
We want to explore it right?
So what are we going to use to find structure in the data?
And so these are sort of natural progressions that any data scientists would do.
But from the perspective of someone trying to model human behavior again, thinking about the biases that exist in the data generating process.
Why was this data collected?

Is the structure I'm seeing a result of that, or is it some actual novel finding that I should start to think more about then of course, as data starts to scale, we need to think about reducing dimensionality and going back to the basics, right?
Univariate data analysis again on the exploratory side, and then once we've found some interesting component of the of the data to look at what we want to actually model well.
Something that something that's very important to everything that we do is that the model is much matched the data, right?

We want to make sure that the model that we're applying to the data set matches the data generating process that we're using and then thinking through well what is the actual best model that we would use.
Um universities are really good at training methods, but one of these fit into a discipline of data science.
From from my perspective as a social science as well.
If we split these things up into two things, what do we know?
Data scientists like and I'm sure we've seen.
We've seen a lot of this week right?
We basically like to do three things.
We like to illustrate the current state of the world.
Dashboards we like to predict future observations, right, predictive modeling, and we like to classify or rank objects something like a recommendation system.
What are social scientists like?
Well, we like theoretical testable models, right?
We like to be able to observe a phenomenon in the world.
Proposed a theory for it, and then test it.
We love natural experiments when they actually occur.
So if there's some opportunity to observe a natural experiment in the world, we want to be able to draw the data out of it, right?
Because we don't get to do real experiments as social scientists, because people don't really like it when you do that to them.
When I talk to Facebook and we like causality.
The sort of big 800 pound gorilla in the room that we often don't get to talk about.
'cause again, we don't get to do real experiments, but when we can, this is.
These are the things that we really care bout.
So how do they?
Things come together into into a discipline of data science.
Well, think about where they're applicable.
Choose the right tool for the right job.
Of course, open up those black boxes in each one of those things.
There may be methods that are useful, but if people don't understand how they're working there, then it's just simply a black box, right?
And then, of course, learn the limitations where in on those things can we actually apply something and work, can't we?
Alright, this to me this is really and now going to the subset of expertise component.
To me this is really the part that sells it for me as a social scientist into data science, right?

I tell people the reason why other folks get to come up on stage and talk about data science and statistic as statistics as the sexiest job of our generation is simply because humans find themselves really sexy in data.
Science is really disciplined that's designed about reflection.
What is it that we can learn about ourselves, right?
What is the most popular kind of, let's say blog post on data science is almost always a map, a heat map?
A density map?
A map about elections, right?

All of these things are super interesting to us, 'cause they're about us and people feel very intimately connected to Maps, and I think that is really a symptom of what data Sciences, which is which is essentially a discipline about human behavior.
And of course, social scientists have a lot to say about human behavior.
That's our whole raison d'etre, right?
That's why that's why we do what we do, and so within these things, for social scientists, again, we sort of split these into two halves, right?
So the first is on the Inquisition side, So what is the question that is actually?

Worth asking or what is the thing that we care about studying in that you know we can start to narrow things down given the area of research that we're doing or the particular size of the data set that we're looking at, you know what kind of questions do we have around scalability and not every method is going to work.
So how do we limit our exploration of questions, right?
Tools are a means to an end.
What's most important here is are you actually asking something that's useful?
Social Sciences have lots of questions, right?
Fundamentally, this is just a bullet of bulleted list of three things.
All of the stuff that we do generate questions that are applicable to probably all the work that everyone in this room is doing.
We care about markets, how people, how individuals and groups behave in them.
We care about organization.
Why do people decide collectively to do anything right?
And of course, decision making either at the atomic level or at the group level.
Again going all the way back to Kelly.
In the beginning.
You know, that's what she cared about.
She wanted to know why people were making the choices that they were, and she ended up studying a very specific.
Kind of decision making, but there's an entire universe of decision making that data scientists and social scientists can work together on.

And then of course the flip end of that is once you've run all this stuff through whatever it is that you're doing, you need interpretability, and I'm actually very glad to followed a talk that was all about interpretability of models, right?
Everyone in this room is probably seen this ex KCD, but I think it remains to be said that this is really at the core of what we want to be able to do as data scientists, which is.
You know if we work in a company an we write a model and a decision maker has to make a choice based on that model.
They just want to know why they're making that choice.
What is it about the thing that you did that actually teaches me something and gives me confidence that I'm making the right choice and all of that comes down to interpretability?
So, as social Sciences we care a lot about this because ultimately we're trying to interpret the results of something for which we have no insight into the true motivation of an individual.
We can only observe actions, or we can only observe.
What they've written or what they said, and so that puts a much larger onus on us in studying the data to have highly interpretable models.

In other versions of this talk, I talk about the hacking component of stuff and say that you know 80% of the work that we do as data scientists really is in that hacking stuff, and there's been some press lately in the New York Times about data scientists as a janitorial work, and I don't think that's inaccurate.
I think a lot of the work that we do is really taking bits and fitting them into squares so that we can start to do math on them, and that takes a lot of time.
But I actually think this component, the substantive expertise component, is where we do 80% of the hard work, which is the thinking.
Right, it's actually, you know, once you know how to use the tools, you can start hacking around a lot.
It might take a lot of man hours, but the thinking hours, the more important stuff.
This is where all the work happens, and it's actually think a tremendous amount of work has already been done in this area by social scientists.
And that's why I think it's so important that we sort of have an open dialogue and have this more interdisciplinary work between social Sciences, data scientists and everyone else.
The brief of rebid on the Danger zone, which was which was referred to later or earlier, I should say, I think, that the danger zone was actually sort of put in.

There is a somewhat tongue in cheek reference at the time when I was writing the diagram, but people people really seemed to appreciate the idea that you know, without any formal math and statistics training, or at least without a kernel of doubt in the work that you're doing, you can do very, very dangerous things, and this applies straight down the line to everything that I've talked about, and so.
Just to highlight this fact, you know, all of us have probably had some training in math and statistics and and it's a great foundation.

But as you start to move into more specific things again, whatever the question is that you're endeavouring to answer, there will be particular methodological things that you actually should probably go back and relearn right as a good student so that you get yourself out of the danger zone.
OK, here's the substantive part of the sandwich, so I got to.
I had a very, very fantastic opportunity over the course of about the last year to work as an advisor right here in the Mayor's Office of Data Analytics here in New York City.

And as it flows through the talk, I want to highlight the work that we've done, 'cause I think it really all of the projects that the Mayor's Office of Data Analytics has done are great examples of all the stuff that I've just talked about, particularly around.

Identifying human problems and then then after the fact figuring out what is the data that we can find to solve that problem, and then finally, how can we create a solution that has some city service delivered more efficiently without inconveniencing the delivers which actually turns out to be the most important thing and again gets back to that interpretability component.
So.
The first bit here.
Well just to give us sorry just to give a quick review of everything that the Mayor's Office of Data Analytics does is sort of broken down into 3 core components.
The first is day-to-day operations.
There is some city service with the city has to deliver to the citizens of New York and that cost money.
So the Mayors Office data analytics is really exist to try to make that city service delivery more efficient.
Through the analysis of data.
So whatever data is being generated through the process of that delivery.
We want to look at it and figure out there's a better way.
Is there some way that we can make this more efficient so that the taxpayers dollar goes further and is used better?

The second part is encouraging economic development, so there's a tremendous amount of data generated here in New York City, about businesses small and large, and the mayor's office, particularly under the previous administration, was very keen on taking that data, delivering it to citizens in a very digestible way, and helping them make choices about their own business or potentially a new business that they would want to start.
And then the last bit, and, you know, certainly the most visceral for New Yorkers is disaster response and sustainability.

We've had some very bad storms here in New York, an A lot of data gets generated anytime that there's a disaster and the mayor's office data analytics work very hard with first responder organizations, as well as other city organizations to try to prepare an also assess when disasters happen.
So the first one I want to talk about.
Is.
The fire Department.
So the fire Department has a very broad mandate to inspect buildings for fire safety.
If there's a hazardous situation in any building in New York City, the fire Department is supposed to rectify the situation, and they usually do that through fines or summons is or even evictions.
If something is particularly bad, and so the fire Department had a method of doing this which was essentially last in first out.
Which was, you know, they would have a huge list of complaints and they would just sit there and they would get filtered down to the appropriate geographic Firehouse.
And then that Firehouse would look at the list an get around to it eventually.
And that's not to say that the firefighters were not doing their job properly.

They have a lot of things to do and they operate on a very very strong budget constraint and so they can only send out a certain number of fire marshals to these buildings when the time allows for it.
And when they think when they think intuitively.

That there may be a higher risk in a building than not, and it's that intuitive component that's important because we know from looking at the data, there are certain kinds of buildings, or there are certain features of buildings that make them much more prone to a fire hazard than others.
So.
What do we do?
We say, OK, let's build a big master table of all the buildings in the city.
An literally do a logistic regression.
That's it.
Just look at that and see what it does.
So that's what we did an I've actually seen a lot of Roc curves today, so I don't feel embarrassed putting this on the screen.
We all know how to read them.
The left panel was the quality of the inspections pre sort of risk based or logistic regression based inspection and you can see the how poor they are doing right?
So first 25% of inspections yield only 25%.
Twenty 1% of severe violations and in this case a severe violation would be one that would require an eviction.
So sort of immediate vacate of a building based on a very very severe problem and lo and behold, if you actually look at the data and you find features and buildings that.
Lend themselves to a much greater risk.
You get an incredible increase in the likelihood that you're going to find these kind of high risk situations and buy higher.
So what are some of the features that that contribute greatly to the model?
Well, some are obvious things like.
Financial liens on the building.
Previous 311 complaints age since last inspection and some of them were much less intuitive like number of garbage complaints on the street tends to be very, very.

As well as number of parking tickets on the street tend to be very, very highly correlated, and of course when you go back to the experts, the firefighters or the boots on the ground who are doing the inspections?

Things like that are very intuitive to them and say Oh well if there's way more garbage on the street and the street is meant to handle either going to summons for apartment of sanitation violation, it means that there's probably overcrowding in the building.
There's more people in the building.
The building is meant to support.
Therefore there's more garbage.
And of course, oh makes perfect sense when you think of it that way.
But none of these things that ever been looked at in concert, and so when we did that.
And use again a very simple model.
We're able to have a very huge increase in the quality of the inspection.

And this is just a sort of visual display of the same information, so you can see that there are these huge gaps in previous models where we thought that there would be a high risk for fire, particularly out down on the shore there and then.
It turns out that there were actually many, many more fires happening there than than we had predicted.
And so again, the model gives us some much, much stronger result.
The next bit here is an economic development, right?

So under the previous administration, they were very, very keen to generate tools that allowed entrepreneurs to much more simply get at data that was freely available to them and give it to them in a way that sort of again was easy to interpret and allow them to make choices about whether or not they wanted to start business or even what the economic state of their neighborhood for, and.
So we created this thing called the New York City business Atlas, which is just a map.
Again, data science 101.
We created a map and what the map does is it creates these sort of chloraprep choropleth pallets of various features of the city.
Things like population growth or population decay, median income and medium amounts of money being spent at various types of businesses in different neighborhoods.
And all this data is freely available through the city.
But no entrepreneur frankly not.

Not very many small business owners are going to have the resources to generate something like this, and I'll be the first to say it's not the most beautiful tool in the world, but it provides a lot of very useful information and you can go to the URL is right there you can go to it right now.
For small businesses, and we've found that they are very, very receptive to this.
Even folks who are or not at all technically inclined find this information very useful.
And the final bit I want to talk on is an emergency response, and so this photo is actually taken from the New York Daily News.
Only a few, maybe a month ago.
And if you're a New Yorker, you may have heard that there's a lot of consternation at City Hall about the response times for 911.
And you can see that 911 is going through some changes from the switchboard level, and they've observed this three minute increase in the time to response.
Why is it that they're even able to observe?
This three minute increase in response and why is it that a free and open press is actually able to hold politicians responsible for a 3 minute increase in response?

It's because we opened up the data and we actually created a tool that allows anyone to go inspect the response times for any number of different kind of #1 calls, and this is actually a very very interesting model running under the hood.
Because then on one call is an extremely complicated event, despite the fact that it might not seem that way.
Any 911 call that goes into the city goes to a dispatcher right in the dispatcher has to decide which of any number of three different.
Kinds of responses.
It's going to get, so then that call gets to another dispatcher and the and the hierarchy continues.
Now that's in a very sort of linear type of call.
Now imagine that you're walking down Broadway and a bus runs into a telephone pole.
When that happens, you get multiple calls at once.
You get multiple calls at once happening in different geographies.

You get multiple calls at once, possibly happening to different switchboard operators responsible for different geographies, and so the model had just sort of resolve all of these things and attempt to create a single time estimate for every single event.
And so that's what manifests itself here in this in this chart.

But actually to me, what's more important about this result is not so much that we created an interesting model that allowed us to find how long the average number one response call was, but actually that that information is now out there in the world.
Again, because now citizens can hold their government responsible for things like this, which we were never able to do before.
And that's a very powerful result driven from data science.
At the end of my talk, I just want to.
I want to sort of look ahead again.

This is the other slice of bread now on the sandwich, I want to sort of look ahead to where I think the most interesting open questions are, and I think the most interesting open questions are at the intersection here, where social science and data science come together and the first one is really around privacy, right?
And so we talk a lot about privacy with respect to access.
Who gets to see what data, how well is everything encrypted?
What are our standards and practices around that?
But for us as.
Analysts, and particularly for us as modelers, we need to start thinking more about what are the limitations of the questions that we should be asking, right we?

I talked a lot about the importance of asking the right question, but I think in equal amount should be talked about and hasn't been talked about a lot or on the importance of not asking a question and so just from what I've heard today, you know, in the last talk we're talking a little bit about predictive policing and creating.
Simple 224 models around choice models around predictive policing.

But of course if those models are derived from data, those models will have the same amount of bias that exists in a police force, and so that's a very topical thing that's happening in our country right now.
But if we were to actually go that way, we have to think about, well, how do we disentangle the bias that exists in that data before we put it into a model?
And I think that's somewhat profound thing to have to think about, and it's our responsibility.
To do it.
Next is on the collaboration between academia and industry.
In this conference is sort of the Crown jewel of that and I'm very happy to be here if people don't know what this is.
This is the Kmart building down in Astor Place, which as an NYU, you graduate student.

I can tell you I spent some time sort of buying cheap things in Kmart 'cause I had no money but very little time in the upper floors and the reason for that is there wasn't really anything in the upper floors until about a year ago when Facebook bought most of it and put their entire AI research group.
In there and took some academics from NYU.
You some very well known academics from why you and put them to work, and so I think right now is the time to be thinking well.
How are we going to work together in the future?
Academics used to be in the place where they had all the great data they were generating it through research grants or their own work, and that was where the interesting things were happening.
Now the tables have turned a bit.
Industry has all the interesting data.
Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn.
They had their generating the interesting data and starting to.
Pull talent out of academia right?
This academic brain drain so we need to start thinking about how we're going to work together so that we have future generations of data scientists to go work with them or work with future academics.
And the final piece here is on where I sort of see the future of our discipline going.

And so I started the talk talking about, you know why do we even have data science and part of it is because we spent so much time thinking about how to analyze information that was happening in the commercial web.
Well, now there's a lot of information that's being generated outside of the web, right through connected devices through low-cost sensors that are in our homes on our bodies.
I'm wearing a heart monitor right now that's connected to my phone.

And now that data doesn't exist on the web, but we're generating a ton of it, and I think there's a lot of technology left to be built on a lot of questions left to be asked about what we're going to do with all this new data.
It's the new frontier, I think, for our discipline, and I'm very, very excited to actually live in a time when we can start to think about that.
And I hope that everyone else in the room is as well, so I'll make one.
Unplug, which is where I work now.
This place called Project Florida.
We kind of do all that stuff right.
The previous slide.
We think about what kind of questions we can and should be answering.
We have very deep collaborations with with research institutions, an we build products and hardware to listen to people's bodies and continuous physiological signals.
So if anybody wants to talk to me about that in particular after the talk, I'd be happy to do that.
And with that, I thank you.
Hey Drew, thanks for the talk.
I'm wondering if you would like to address the elephant in the room with regard to why data scientists go to ad tech Facebook anyway, people who generate revenue of attention.
Do you see any changes or maybe any advocacy that's required around the pay rate of public servants?
The respect that allocated to the public sector in the States and also one other issue which influences me is just.
How public institutions bureaucratized data and politicize it.

If you go to a startup, you know often you're giving the keys to all the tables, but it seems like the real benefit would be from aggregating information across different departments, and I feel like if I went to the city it would be 10 years before I could do a join across departments.
Maybe that's not true anymore, but in other cities, and maybe right now, that's an excellent question I saw.
I think there's sort of two parts to it.
One is most of the interesting data or the resources to do interesting stuff with large amounts of data.
Exist outside of government, so to get to your question about doing a joint across the city again, it was only very recently that that would even be feasible.
Then the other side of, I think is economic of course, but what I tell people who are thinking about starting careers, saying have a choice.

If you have a choice between going into industry or, say, going into public service at the beginning of your karere, you will have access to questions and the results of your answers will go all the way down to touch a citizen right as they would in the Mayor's Office of Data Analytics.
Or for me when I started my career in the federal government, you know all the way out to the field commander in Afghanistan.
And I think there's a profound responsibility and quite a lot of hard work that goes into sort of thinking about taking a job in that way.

The selfish side taking a job in that way means that when you're out of that career, or you feel like you want to move on to something else, your portfolio is 10 times more impressive than someone who hasn't, whose maybe work only in industry.
You've actually done work, at least in my eyes.
That's had a much larger effect on the world.
Alright, I'm from the social science background as well and I was curious about your thoughts on.
So much of data science right now seems focused on data derived from social media or online sales, and that still represents a fairly narrow swath of our society.
And it seems like.
Often there's a mistake made of drawing general conclusions based on that data an I don't.
I don't hear that talked about very much.
I think you're exactly I think you're.
I mean, I don't have much to say other than I agree with you.
I think that you know, I think there are two sides to it.
One is, I'm very happy that social scientists who have, you know, an interest or an acumen in sort of.
Interrogating questions on Twitter by learning the tools that are required to actually pull that data out are great.
I'm confident that well trained social scientists will.
Then of course, caveat everything that they're doing with the bias that exists in the sample.
Given all the constraints that you just said, I think that's exactly right.
I mean, models of political choice that are based on Twitter data have not done well.
There's a good reason for it, because it's only a small sample of people who actually vote are on Twitter.
Hi Drew, thanks for your talk.
I'm wondering if you can talk a little.
I mean, it seems like people in this room.
Many people have an interest in.

Data science for socially good applications, and there's probably a range of people who want to spend the rest of their lives on it to people who could maybe do a little bit of pro bono work couple hours a week, five hours a week or something.
Then I guess I wonder if you can talk about the data kind model and how well it's worked.
And I also kind of wonder what other models you've thought about.
Maybe tried and didn't workout.
Or you know, maybe like open source projects, type stuff or other models that you're thinking about trying to kind of engage this sort of.

Kinds of responses.

Now that's in a very sort of linear type of call.
